prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LBQS0109
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Intensity mapping of the CO(3-2) line in a z~2.35 quasar over the whole line width and in the high velocity wings.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Estimate of expected CO(3-2) flux: LBQS0109+02 has been detected in Herschel observations available in the archive. Using an SMG/QSO template we estimate a total infrared luminosity (8-1000micron) of 2.6x10^13 Lsun. According to the LFIR-LCO' relation for SMGs and QSOs (Carilli & Wang 2013) and a QSO SLED (average CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) = 0.97, Carilli & Walter 2013) this corresponds to a total flux for CO(3-2) of ~4 Jy KM/SEC. The use of the Daddi et al. 2010 relation for disk galaxies and conversion factor and CO SLED typical of the Milky Way would increase that estimate by a factor ~2. We could estimate the expected line flux using the narrow Halpha formation detected in our K band observations. The reddening uncorrected Halpha luminosity for LBQS0109+02 is similar to that of 2QZJ002830.4-281706 and, following the analysis performed for that source, we would obtain an expecetd total CO(3-2) flux of 0.25 Jy KM/SEC, a factor 16 less than obtained from FIR emission. This strenghten the fact that the estimates for the two other sources based on reddening uncorrected narrow Halpha emission are likely underestimated by a factor ~20.
Sensitivity: The source LBQS0109+02 has an expected extension of 0.5" x 1" which, combined with a linewidth of ~150 km/s, provides an expected flux of ~10 mJy/beam. With 1 hours of total observing time, it will be possible to reach a sensitivity over the integrated flux map of 0.2 mJy, which will allow a high signal to noise image of the starforming cold molecular gas. We will also be able to detect faint emission due to fast outflowing molecular gas with a signal to noise of ~5 down to 1 mJy/beam, i.e. 1/10 of the total flux. This is the expected ratio between the main component and the fast molecular outflow component (eg Feruglio et al. 2010,2015 and Cicone et al. 2013).
Calibration: standard calibration is fine.
Scheduling/time constraints: we do not have any time constraints.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: we do not have any special constraints.

At the redshift of the source (z=2.350) the CO(3-2) line is redshifted to at 103.2 GHz, in band 3. We placed the line in the upper side band to have good atmospheric transmission also in the lower side band. The expected line widths are of the order of 150 km/s, or lower, therefore we request a spectral setup with a a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a resolution of 3.9 MHz (~12 km/s) which is good sampling of the line profile. The two adjacent spectral windows in the upper sideband, overlapping by ~300MHz, will ensure a continuos spectral coverage. We do not require any special correlator setup.
Bandpass accuracy: the CO(3-2) line will be centered in one spectral window and its width is much smaller than the bandwidth, therefore we do not have any special request on the bandpass accuracy.
Data rate: our spectral setup requires a low data rate.

The chosen angular resolution is a nice match to that of our SINFONI observations (~0.6"). The largest angular scale is that directly measured from our SINFONI observations (~1"). The sources are small and will have a relatively simple structure at the resolution of the proposed observations, therefore we do not require special configurations for imaging.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 2QZJ0028
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Intensity mapping of the CO(3-2) line in a z~2.4 quasar over the whole line width.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Estimate of the expected CO(3-2) flux. The narrow Halpha emission (uncorrected for reddening) in 2QZJ002830.4-281706 traces star formation and is spatially resolved. It correspond to a SFR~100 Msun/yr (Cano Diaz et al. 2012). Using the relation of Kennicutt & Evans (2013) it corresponds to LFIR~10^12 Lsun. According to the LFIR-LCO' relation for SMGs and QSOs (Carilli & Wang 2013) and a QSO SLED (average CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) = 0.97, Carilli & Walter 2013) this corresponds to a total flux for CO(3-2) of ~0.25 Jy KM/SEC. The use of the Daddi et al. 2010 relation for disk galaxies and conversion factor and CO SLED typical of the Milky Way would increase that estimate by a factor ~2. We stress that this is very likely a LOWER LIMIT since the narrow Halpha emission has NOT been corrected for reddening; a recent study by Dominguez Sanchez et al. (2013) in a sample of z~ 0.1-0.5 galaxies find that Halpha and L_IR (infrared luminosity) provide consistent estimates of SFRs when Halpha has been reddening corrected; on average reddening is correlated with IR luminosity and becomes E(B-V)~ 1 for L_IR~10^12 Lsun. In this case a correction of ~20 should be applied to H$\alpha$ and consequently to the expected CO flux. In our target LBQS0109, the expected CO(3-2) line flux from narrow Halpha emission is a factor 16 lower than that estimated from FIR luminosity, confirming that a correction of at least a factor ~20 is expected.
Sensitivity: The source 2QZJ002830.4-281706 has an expected extension of ~0.5" x 1" which, combined with a linewidth of ~150 km/s, provides an expected flux of ~0.8 mJy/beam. With 1 hour of total observing time, it will be possible to reach a sensitivity over the integrated flux map of 0.2 mJy, which will allow to detect the molecular gas with a signal to noise of ~4, which, as shown in the simulations, is adequate for our goals.
Calibration: standard calibration is fine.
Scheduling/time constraints: we do not have any time constraints.
Data rate: our spectral setup requires a low data rate.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: we do not have any special constraints.

Correlator setup: at the redshift of the source (z=2.41) the CO(3-2) line is redshifted to at 101.6 GHz, in band 3. We placed the line in the upper side band to have good atmospheric transmission also in the lower side band. The expected line widths are of the order of 150 km/s, or lower, therefore we request a spectral setup with a a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a resolution of 3.9 MHz (~12 km/s). The two adjacent spectral windows in the upper sideband, overlapping by ~300MHz, will ensure a continuos spectral coverage. We do not require any special correlator setup.
Bandpass accuracy: the CO(3-2) line will be centered in one spectral window and its width is much smaller than the bandwidth, therefore we do not have any special request on the bandpass accuracy.

The chosen angular resolution is a nice match to that of our SINFONI observations (~0.6"). The largest angular scale is that directly measured from our SINFONI observations (~1"). The sources are small and will have a relatively simple structure at the resolution of the proposed observations, therefore we do not require special configurations for imaging.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HB890329
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Intensity mapping of the CO(3-2) line in a z~2.4 quasar over the whole line width.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Estimate of the expected CO(3-2) flux. The narrow Halpha emission in HB89 0329-385 traces star formation and is spatially resolved. Its total luminosity is a factor 1.5 larger than that of 2QZJ002830.4-281706. Following the same analysis we can then simply expect a CO (3-2) flux which is a factor 1.5 larger, i.e. 0.4 Jy KM/SEC. Again, we stress that this is very likely a LOWER LIMIT since the narrow Halpha emission has NOT been corrected for reddening; as shown earlier, a correction of ~20 should be applied to the expected CO flux.
Sensitivity: The source HB89 0329-385 has an expected extension of ~0.5" x 1" which, combined with a linewidth of ~150 km/s, provides an expected flux of ~1.2 mJy/beam. With 1 hour of total observing time, it will be possible to reach a sensitivity over the integrated flux map of 0.2 mJy, which will allow to detect the molecular gas with a signal to noise of ~6, which, as shown in the simulations, is adequate for our goals.
Calibration: standard calibration is fine.
Scheduling/time constraints: we do not have any time constraints.
Data rate: our spectral setup requires a low data rate.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: we do not have any special constraints.

Correlator setup: at the redshift of the source (z=2.44) the CO(3-2) line is redshifted to at 100.5 GHz, in band 3. We placed the line in the upper side band to have good atmospheric transmission also in the lower side band. The expected line widths are of the order of 150 km/s, or lower, therefore we request a spectral setup with a a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a resolution of 3.9 MHz (~12 km/s). The two adjacent spectral windows in the upper sideband, overlapping by ~300MHz, will ensure a continuos spectral coverage. We do not require any special correlator setup.
Bandpass accuracy: the CO(3-2) line will be centered in one spectral window and its width is much smaller than the bandwidth, therefore we do not have any special request on the bandpass accuracy.

The chosen angular resolution is a nice match to that of our SINFONI observations (~0.6"). The largest angular scale is that directly measured from our SINFONI observations (~1"). The sources are small and will have a relatively simple structure at the resolution of the proposed observations, therefore we do not require special configurations for imaging.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: According to theoretical models, quasar driven outflows at high redshift clean massive galaxies of their gas content and quench star formation. We have recently discovered powerful AGN-driven outflows by studying the velocity field of [OIII]5007 in three quasars at z~2.4. The spatial distribution of the starforming regions in their host galaxies is anticorrelated with the presence of fast outflows, providing the very first evidence of quasar feedback quenching star formation. However, this evidence is tentative as it is based only on rest-frame optical spectra. We propose to map CO(3-2) to trace the distribution of the cold molecular gas in the three quasars, the only ones known so far showing evidence of outflows quenching star formation. The CO(3-2) maps will be compared with our [OIII] maps with similar spatial resolution: the molecular gas should be absent in the outflow dominated region, while surviving in the rest of the galaxy. This would be the first direct confirmation of star formation quenching by quasar outflows. Our ALMA observations will then open the way for the physical characterization of quasar driven feedback in larger samples of objects.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is a resubmission of a proposal ranked in the top 10-20% in Cycle 2 (2013.1.00965.S), for which observations have not been performed yet. We wish to perform these observations in Cycle 3. Compared to the Cycle 2 submission (1.3h ? 2 = 2.6h request), we have added one additional target for which we now have evidence of star formation quenching by fast outflows (1h ? 3 = 3h request). In case the two targets approved in Cycle 2 are observed before the beginning of Cycle 3, we ask only to observe the new target (1h).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
